title: Serif font to accompany Cholla Sans & Slab
content: What would be a good serif font to accompany Cholla Sans & Slab fonts for a technical guide? I had been using Weidemann Book and liked the light, compact feel but feel it's a bit old fashioned and was going to switch to Rotis Semi Serif to give it a more modern look but that font seems funny. Other fonts I looked at were Trump Medieveal, Swift, Apollo, and they all kind of have more of a book reading feel and not really technical guide. Any suggestions?
author: wyclef

comments.content: The reason Rotis feels funny is that it was made like a engineering plan, not a typeface. I would look at a modern, sturdy Dutch face like [Oranda](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415223943/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/bitstream/oranda_ot/), [FF Olsen](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415223943/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=Olsen), or [FF Nexus Mix](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415223943/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_nexus_mix_ot/).

I used to do this magazine in which I used Cholla sans & slab with [Neutraliser](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415223943/http:/www.t26.com/fonts/961-Neutraliser-Sans) for bodytext. May sound weird, but worked out fine.

Not a serif typeface, but for some reason I was thinking a sans like [Klaivika](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415223943/http:/www.processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/klavika/index.html) might work well.

For a serif, how about [Meta Serif](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415223943/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=meta+serif&x=0&y=0)?
